2016 Connecticut Civic Health Index Dashboard

A deeper analysis reveals notable differences in civic engagement based on demographic characteristics, including age, gender, and race or ethnicity. These distinctions highlight the motivations behind participation in certain activities as well as some of the barriers to vibrant civic health facing certain groups. For many civic activities, differential participation rates have origins more profound than individual choice and may be emblematic of systemic inequities.1

The 2011 Connecticut Civic Health Index Report noted patterns of engagement based on economic factors, which 2015 data continue to reflect. Civic engagement correlates strongly with education and income. Generally, it is highest among college-educated adults or residents of top-earning households, with the exception of some indicators of social interaction.

Civic Health by Education in Connecticut

Data is pooled from 2010, 2011, 2013

NCoC Analysis of 2013 Census Current Population Survey

Civic participation increases with age, according to measures in this Index. Generally, young adults demonstrate the lowest rates of engagement, which peak among older adults, including the Baby Boomer Generation or the Silent Generation. Civic data reflect the relative political disengagement of Connecticut youth.

Civic Health by Age in Connecticut

Data is pooled from 2010, 2011, 2013

NCoC Analysis of 2013 Census Current Population Survey

In most spheres of civic health, women are slightly more engaged than men. But for certain activities, exceptional gender-based distinctions arise. For example, in 2013 women were much more likely to volunteer than men (31.1% and 24.2% respectively), or to be involved in school, neighborhood, or community groups and with religious institutions. Yet a significantly larger share of men than women participated in sports or recreation groups and service or civic associations. Notwithstanding these findings, participation of women in Connecticut’s state boards and commissions continues to lag behind that of their male counterparts.

Political Participation by Gender in Connecticut

NCoC Analysis of 2013 Census Current Population Survey

Statewide, engagement in civic activities varies between racial and ethnic groups. In general, White followed by African American/Black residents have the highest levels of involvement, while Asian American and Latino adults demonstrate lower participation. However, many distinctions in civic habits based on race or ethnicity may be related to larger socioeconomic and structural inequities

Connecticut Registration and Voting Rates in 2012 by Race/Ethnicity

NCoC Analysis of 2013 Census Current Population Survey

Connecticut Group Participation by Race and Ethnicity

NCoC Analysis of 2013 Census Current Population Survey

In addition to the aforementioned characteristics, the propensity of racial and ethnic minorities to be young and to switch residences may cause their participation rates in these civic activities to generally be lower than Whites’

Population Characteristics by Race and Ethnicity (2013)

U.S. Census, American Community Survey 5-year estimates, 2009-13

Examining subsets of the population demonstrates that civic participation differs depending on demographic characteristics.

1. Unless otherwise noted, all text on this website taken from Buchanan et al., 2016 Connecticut Civic Health Index http://bit.ly/1PdUnKZ.
